178800662.description:
Erik Cunningham is a member of Twitter's engineering team in Boulder and will be discussing the Raft consensus algorithm.  Erik will also (hopefully) be going over an easy-to-visualize Raft implementation so we can run through behavior/failure modes during his talk.

A large round of thanks go to Josh Kaiser for hosting this month's Meetup at the new SendGrid office.  We'll have food, drinks and good old fashioned socializing from 6-6:30, then start the presentation at 6:30.  John will also bring along a bottle of his latest batch of homebrewed wine for any interested parties.

We've set aside enough time for Erik to give his presentation and answer any questions at the end.
178800662.title: PWL CO #2: In Search of an Understandable Consensus Algorithm

178845982.description:
Dave Rusek is an engineer at Twitter and will discuss The Staged Event-Driven Architecture for Highly-Concurrent Server Applications.

We'll be socializing from 6 until 6:30 and Dave will start around 6:30.
178845982.title: PWL CO #3: The SEDA Paper

171976382.description:
John Claus will be discussing Google's Dapper paper, a tracing system used by Google for debugging large scale distributed systems.

The people at Oracle have been gracious enough to offer their space for our first meeting.  Feel free to show up from 6 to 6:45 for beer, pizza and socializing.  We'll aim to get started by 6:45, which should give ample time to discuss the paper and leave time at the end for questions.

The Oracle office is on the southeast corner of 13th & Walnut.  Please follow signs pointing towards the east entrance of the building.

If you're driving into Boulder for the event, the Boulder Transit Center offers parking just off 14th & Walnut.  There's also a parking lot across from Oracle, on the northwest corner of 13th & Walnut.
171976382.title: PWL CO #1: Dapper, a Large-Scale Distributed Systems Tracing Infrastructure

178847172.description:
Tim Schmelmer is on the engineering team at LivingSocial and will give a presentation on the Kafka paper.

We will post more details about this talk as the date approaches.
178847172.title: PWL CO #4: Kafka: a Distributed Messaging System for Log Processing

221122139.description:
Abstract:

a ∧ ¬(b ∨ a). Is there some assignment to a and b that makes the expression true? This is the well known problem of Boolean satisfiability (SAT). This problem can be extended to predicates over non-Boolean values. For example, is the following satisfiable? (c < d) ∧ (d ≤ c + 1). This extended problem is known as Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT). In this talk, I will present an introduction to SMT and its many applications, from scheduling to static program analysis to dependency resolution. I will end with concrete examples, demonstrating how to use an SMT solver from Haskell to prove assertions about a program.

Bio:

Alex is software developer interested in using modern techniques to write more reliable programs, and is particularly optimistic about the intersection of industry and academia. Other times, he'd rather be outside. He's currently a software engineer at Twitter.
221122139.title: PWL CO #5: Satisfiability Modulo Theories: Introduction and Applications
